My comment is harsh, so be prepared for it: this attitude makes me si=
ck to my stomach.

It is *not* all right for the application to crash when =
something simple goes wrong. There will always be very difficult problems t=
hat we cannot solve in time to ship the product, but failure to handle an e=
xception must not automatically be considered less important than correctly=
 handling the "happy paths".

>2. Fails if wrong exception class thrown or =
nothing was thrown.

That's not always enough: does the exception object th=
rown contain adequate information to describe the exception?

Exception tes=
ts in particular are more of a design tool than a testing tool: writing goo=
d exception tests leads to better exception classes, which leads to higher =
serviceability and maintainability, which saves lots of money down the line=
 trying to track down difficult-to-diagnose problems at the client site. Pe=
ople who do not practise TDD probably think exception tests are a waste of =
time and they wouldn't be far off. Exception tests show their value most in=
 the context of TDD.

>3. Typical exception cause is wrong method parameter=
s or 
>preconditions. So it takes a lot of tests to be written to create 
>=
different exceptional conditions.

Wrong method parameters or failed precon=
ditions indicate a bug elsewhere, and not a bug in the method trying to rec=
eive those parameters. It usually indicates that the caller is not adequate=
ly tested. "Defensive programming" is truly paranoid programming and should=
 be avoided.
